meanings.definition: The state of being degraded or humiliated.
meanings.sent1: The abjection of the poor man made everyone feel sad.
meanings.sent2: She felt a deep sense of abjection after being publicly criticized.
meanings.sent3: The abjection of the spoiled food in the fridge was evident from the foul smell.
meanings.sent4: The abandoned house stood in abjection, a shadow of its former glory.
meanings.sent5: The abjection of the fallen hero was a stark reminder of the harsh realities of life.

meanings.definition: A feeling of disgust or revulsion.
meanings.sent1: The sight of the decaying food filled her with abjection.
meanings.sent2: He couldn't hide his abjection when faced with the gruesome scene.
meanings.sent3: The abjection of the slimy slug made the children squeal in disgust.
meanings.sent4: The abjection of the crime scene left a lasting impression on the detective.
meanings.sent5: The abjection of the foul odor lingered in the room long after the source was removed.

meanings.definition: The act of rejecting or casting off.
meanings.sent1: The abjection of the old traditions paved the way for new ideas.
meanings.sent2: She felt a sense of abjection as she discarded the broken toy.
meanings.sent3: The abjection of the outdated technology was necessary for progress.
meanings.sent4: The abjection of the toxic relationship was a relief for both parties.
meanings.sent5: The abjection of the old ways brought about a sense of liberation in the community.
